sections.title: Early Learning STEM Australia
sections.subtitle: A new learning initiative for Australia

blurbs.title: Preschool
blurbs.body: Early Learning STEM Australia (ELSA) is a play-based digital learning program for children in preschool to explore Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM).

blurbs.title: Digital
blurbs.body: ELSA apps will go beyond the screen to encourage active play that supports STEM practices, such as exploring location, patterns and problem solving. Our apps support learning through play, and act as a springboard for children to explore the natural world.

blurbs.title: Pilot
blurbs.body: We are looking for a hundred preschools  from across Australia  to join the 2018 ELSA Pilot. Express your interest before 10 April for a chance to be involved in this innovative learning program.

sections.title: Providing the best learning outcomes
sections.subtitle: Benefits of joining the ELSA Pilot.
content: In 2018, a hundred preschools across Australia will take part in the ELSA Pilot. These preschools will receive free workshops and be the first to use the ELSA apps and resources to incorporate STEM practices into their preschool program.
STEM practices include exploring place and patterns, problem solving, designing, making, and spatial reasoning.

Exploring STEM practices helps children weave strong skill ropes in problem solving and communication that can be used in many ways in later life. Apply to join the ELSA Pilot to receive the following benefits:
+ More confidence in exploring STEM in your preschool to provide the best learning outcomes for children.
+ A host of resources aligned with the Early Years Learning Framework and linked to the Australian Curriculum, plus ways to share ideas with other early learning professionals.
+ New ways to engage families through the ELSA family suite, which will extend the learning into home.
+ Innovative ideas for children to explore, investigate and have meaningful experiences in the natural world.
ELSA is free. All you need is a tablet device for children to play with, or a commitment to buy a device if your centre is selected.

timeline.title: Starting in 2018
timeline.body: A hundred centres across Australia will take part in the ELSA Pilot. These centres will be the first to try the ELSA Program, and receive free workshops and resources about incorporating STEM into their preschool program.

timeline.title: Applying is easy
timeline.body: Simply send in details about your centre to register. We are looking for a diverse range of centres to represent the diversity found across Australia. So whether your preschool is urban, regional or remote, large or small, government, community, independent, or anything else, we want to include you.

timeline.title: Eligibility
timeline.body: To take part you  need is a preschool program and a tablet device for children to use, such as an iPad or Android tablet.e If you don’t have a tablet, you can commit to purchasing one before October if you are selected. There is no cost for ELSA, but ELSA does not provide funding for devices. Check the participation guidelines for more.

sections.title: FAQ
sections.subtitle: Extra bits of information you might need.

questions.q: What is Early Learning STEM Australia (ELSA)?
a: Early Learning STEM Australia (ELSA) is a program for early learning educators to provide opportunities for preschool children to engage in STEM practices. The program will be delivered via a series of digital applications, activities and workshops to create a play based learning environment rich in STEM practices, such as exploring locations, patterns, cause and effect and problem solving.

ELSA is a key early childhood initiative of the Australian Government’s National Innovation and Science Agenda. It supports the Inspiring all Australians in digital literacy and STEM measure, which seeks to increase the participation of Australian children in STEM and improve their digital literacy.
STEM is an integrated way to teach approach to teaching science, technology, engineering and mathematics by exploring the real world.
You use STEM at your preschool when children:
+ Create a community garden
+ Build structures that are strong or tall
+ Fill different containers with water or sand
+ Create patterns or draw designs

STEM practices include exploring place and patterns, problem solving, designing, making, and spatial reasoning. Exploring STEM practices helps children weave strong skill ropes in problem solving and communication that can be used in many ways in later life.

questions.q: What do you mean by preschool?
a: We define a preschool as a structured, play based learning program, delivered by a degree qualified teacher, aimed primarily at children in the year or two before they commence full time schooling.

Expressions of interest to participate in the Pilot are open to any service that provides a preschool program. This includes kindergartens, long day care centres, stand-alone preschools, community preschools, preschools attached to a school and other types of preschools.

questions.q: What are the eligibility criteria to express interest in the ELSA Pilot?
a: 1. Offer a preschool program that is provided primarily to children in the year before full-time school.
2. The preschool program must be delivered by a degree-qualified early childhood teacher (as per ACECQA), unless you have a waiver from ACECQA (for example, if you are located in a remote area.)
3. Internet access and WiFi connection.
4. Have one or more tablet devices (Android or iPad) that children can use for the ELSA Pilot, or make a commitment to purchase these before October 2017 if you are selected for the Pilot.

questions.q: How can I join the Pilot?
a: To register your interest for the ELSA Pilot, please fill out the online form located [here](register.html) between 27 February and 10 April 2017.

One hundred preschools across Australia will be involved in the 2018 ELSA Pilot. Preschools will be selected so that the Pilot represents diversity across Australia. For more information, read the [Participation Guidelines](eligibility.html). Outcomes of the expression of interest process will be advised in August 2017.

Participating educators will start their ELSA journey in Term 4 2017 through a face-to-face workshop with the ELSA Program team (educators from the University of Canberra and other Australian educational institutions). The program will start in preschools in Term 1 2018. Apps and further workshops will be rolled out during 2018.

questions.q: What is involved for a centre in the Pilot?
a: Being involved in the ELSA Pilot will be a rich and rewarding professional experience. Pilot preschools will need to commit to providing and supporting tablet devices in their learning environments. You will need an active internet and WiFi connection to download the resources as they become available throughout 2018.

Pilot preschools will need to commit dedicated time (approximately 40 minutes per child per week, in total in accordance with national screen time guidelines) to use the apps and experience the program. You will also be involved by contributing your feedback and reflections on the Pilot and participating in an evaluation of ELSA.

questions.q: Can I be involved in the Pilot if my preschool doesn’t have tablet?
a: You will need a tablet to be in the Pilot. If you don’t have a tablet, you can still apply by making a commitment to purchase one by October 2017 if you are selected for the Pilot. You can make this commitment when you fill out the application form. The apps will operate on iPad and Android tablets.

questions.q: Is there any cost to participate?
a: There is no cost to participate in the Pilot. However, the Pilot operates on a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) model where preschools supply tablet devices and adequate internet and WiFi connections. These costs are the responsibility of the preschool.

questions.q: Do I need to have a science background to be involved?
a: Not at all. ELSA is more about STEM practices than content. Educators already adopt a STEM practices approach by encouraging children to ask questions, make predictions, try things, and reflect on what happened and why. By participating in ELSA, educators and families will find new ways for children to engage with STEM practices.

questions.q: Can I get help with tablets and digital technology?
a: Absolutely. The ELSA Pilot will support educators get a handle on tablets and digital learning. There will be an ELSA helpdesk with support available to answer any tech questions you might have.
Educators need to be degree-qualified to be involved formally in the ELSA Pilot.
ELSA will use tablet apps to create meaningful opportunities for children to explore rich digital learning environments.

Children are expected to spend up to a maximum of 40 minutes per week engaging with the ELSA apps. This is likely to occur across multiple shorter sessions, and is consistent with screen time guidelines from the Australian Government. The apps are being carefully designed with early childhood experts to support active play.

questions.q: Is my privacy protected? What data will be collected?
a: We take privacy seriously. The privacy of all participants, including children, educators and families, will be protected when participating in the ELSA Pilot.

For example, data on app usage will be collected to help us improve the program. This data will be stored securely on Australian servers, and children will not be identified in this data. If you have any questions about privacy, please contact us at [team@elsa.edu.au](mailto:team@elsa.edu.au)
Yes. Families are encouraged to engage with the ELSA Pilot. We are developing a family suite that includes an app and resources to support connection between children’s homes and preschools.
